problem.title: The problem isn't your willpower
problem.text1: Apps are designed by teams of engineers to capture your attention. Notifications, infinite feeds, algorithms... everything is optimized to bring you back.
problem.text2: HoldOn doesn't judge you. HoldOn simply gives you a moment to pause.

features.title: How does it work?
features.subtitle: Simple. Kind. Effective.
features.step1_text: Select the apps you want to pause before opening (social media, games, etc.)
features.step2_text: When you open a targeted app, a meditative screen appears for a few seconds with a mindfulness exercise.
features.step3_text: After the pause, you choose: continue to the app or return to the present moment. It's your decision.

meditations.title: 3 types of meditations
meditations.subtitle: Each app opening is a new opportunity to refocus
meditations.breathing_text: Follow the gently pulsing circle. Inhale as it grows, exhale as it contracts.
meditations.sounds_text: Close your eyes for a moment and identify three distinct sounds around you.
meditations.sensations_text: Reconnect with your body. Feel your feet on the ground, your hands, your breathing.

science.title: Why does it work?
science.subtitle: An approach validated by neuroscience research
science.card1_text: Between the stimulus (wanting to open Instagram) and the response (opening it), there's a space. By creating a pause of a few seconds, HoldOn expands this space and allows you to consciously choose rather than react automatically.
science.card2_text: Studies show that even short mindfulness practices (less than 10 minutes) significantly reduce impulsive behaviors and improve self-regulation.
science.card3_text: When you have to confirm your choice to open an app, you switch from "autopilot" mode to conscious mode. This simple friction is often enough to break the automatic cycle.
science.card3_cite: — BJ Fogg, Stanford Behavior Design Lab
science.card4_text: Slow, deep breathing activates the parasympathetic nervous system, reducing the stress and anxiety that often drive us to seek distraction on our phones.
